review.title: Automatic Construction of Discourse Corpora for Dialogue Translation
review.abstract: In this paper, a novel approach is proposed to automatically construct parallel discourse corpus for dialogue machine translation. Firstly, the parallel subtitle data and its corresponding monolingual movie script data are crawled and collected from Internet. Then tags such as speaker and discourse boundary from the script data are projected to its subtitle data via an information retrieval approach in order to map monolingual discourse to bilingual texts. We not only evaluate the mapping results, but also integrate speaker information into the translation. Experiments show our proposed method can achieve 81.79% and 98.64% accuracy on speaker and dialogue boundary annotation, and speaker-based language model adaptation can obtain around 0.5 BLEU points improvement in translation qualities. Finally, we publicly release around 100K parallel discourse data with manual speaker and dialogue boundary annotation.

sections.heading: 3.1. Script and Subtitle
sections.text: Figure 1 shows a browser snapshot that illustrates an episode script layout of Friends. There are three types of information: speaker, shot / scene, and action information in the script. The speaker element (red ellipses) contains the corresponding character that says the utterance (s). For example, the keywords "SCENE J" and "CUT TO:" refer to the beginning and end of a dialog. The action (green frame) contains all additional information of a narrative nature and explains what happens in the scene. In this work, we focus on the first two types of information, but ignore the final one. Figure 2 is the corresponding bilingual subtitle of the script in Figure 1. Subtitles are often organized into two formats: Advanced SubStation Alpha (ASS) and SubRip (Chinese script), both of which we associate with one line.

sections.heading: 4. Experiments and Results
sections.text: For the dialogue corpus construction, we apply our methods to a ten-year sitcom Friends. We extract and process both scripts and subtitles from friends (described in Section 3.1) and then bridge them (described in Section 3.2) to build a dialogue corpus in the format of Figure 3. For data processing, we use the sentence splitter and the English toolkit and our internal Chinese segmentor (Wang et al., 2012b). In addition, we deal with indexing and search tasks. Table 1 presents the main statistics of the resulting bilingual dialogue corpus. We receive 5,428 bilingual dialogs with the logged-in speaker and the dialogue.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusions and Future Work
sections.text: We propose a novel approach to build a parallel dialogue corpus out of monolingual scripts and their corresponding bilingual subtitles. We identify the dialogue boundaries according to the scene or shoot tags in the script to segment the monolingual dialogue, and then assign the appropriate monolingual dialogues to the source part of the bilingual subtitles to obtain the bilingual discourse dialogues. Finally, we align the bilingual dialogue subtitles lines to produce appropriate MT training material. We expand the current resources of dialogue generation from movie scripts to movie / episode scripts and specify the current parallel corpus construction to bilingual dialogue corpus based on bilingual subtitles. We pilot this approach on a 10-year sitcom Friends and automatically generate 5,428 bilingual parallel dialogues. This is a quick way to manually compare the bilingual dialog corpus to a bilingual subtitle.
